[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] The RopGetHierarchyTable ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.13) is used to retrieve the hierarchy table for a folder.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] The folder can be either a public folder [or a private mailbox folder].
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] The folder can be either [a public folder or] a private mailbox folder.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] This ROP [RopGetHierarchyTable] returns a Table object on which table operations can be performed.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] For details about Table objects and table operations, see [MS-OXCTABL].
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetHierarchyTable ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.13.1).

[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] InputHandleIndex (1 byte): An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the input Server object is stored.

[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] InputHandleIndex (1 byte): The input Server object for this operation [RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] is a Folder object that represents the folder whose hierarchy table will be retrieved.

[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the output Server object is stored.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): The output Server object for this operation [RopGetHierarchyTable ROP] is a Table object that represents the hierarchy table.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): For more details about Table objects, see [MS-OXCTABL].
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): A set of bits that control how information is returned in the hierarchy table.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): The valid bits [0x04, 0x08, 0x10, 0x20, 0x40, 0x80] for this field [TableFlags] are listed in the following table.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): The client MUST NOT set any other bits.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): If this bit [Depth (0x04)] is set, the hierarchy table lists folders from all levels under the folder.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): If this bit [Depth (0x04)] is not set, the hierarchy table lists only the folder's immediate child folders.

[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): DeferredErrors (0x08) means that the ROP response is returned immediately, possibly before the ROP execution is complete, and in this case, the values of the ReturnValue and the RowCount fields of the ROP response buffer might not be accurate.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): NoNotifications (0x10) means that the hierarchy table notifications to the client are disabled.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): If this bit [SoftDeletes (0x20)] is set, the hierarchy table lists only the folders that are soft deleted.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): If this bit [SoftDeletes (0x20)] is not set, the hierarchy table lists only the existing folders.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] The listing of soft-deleted folders in a folder's hierarchy table depends on whether the soft-deleted folders remain part of that folder's hierarchy.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] The location where soft-deleted folders are stored is up to the implementer of the protocol.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): If this bit [UseUnicode (0x40)] is set, the columns that contain string data are returned in Unicode format.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): If this bit [UseUnicode (0x40)] is not set, the string data is encoded in the code page of the Logon object.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): SuppressesNotifications (0x80) means that the notifications generated by the client's actions on the hierarchy table are suppressed.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetHierarchyTable ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.13.2).
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): An integer that indicates the result of the operation.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R317, MS-OXCFOLD_R657, MS-OXCFOLD_R658.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): The server returns 0x00000000 to indicate success.
[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): For details about common error codes, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.

[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): If the TableFlags field of the ROP request buffer has the DeferredErrors bit set, the value of the ReturnValue field is valid only if it indicates a failure
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R803.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] RowCount (4 bytes): An integer that specifies the number of rows in the hierarchy table.

[In RopGetHierarchyTable ROP Response Buffer] RowCount (4 bytes): If the TableFlags field of the ROP request buffer has the DeferredErrors bit set, the value of the RowCount field might not be accurate.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] The RopGetContentsTable ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14) is used to retrieve the contents table for a folder.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] This ROP [RopGetContentsTable] applies to both public folders [and private mailboxes].
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] This ROP [RopGetContentsTable] applies to [both public folders and] private mailboxes.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] This ROP [RopGetContentsTable] returns a Table object on which table operations can be performed.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] For example, the table's columns, which represent properties, can be set by using the RopSetColumns ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.5.1).
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] For details about Table objects and table operations, see [MS-OXCTABL].
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] The complete syntax of the ROP request buffer and the ROP response buffer is specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP] This section specifies the syntax and semantics of various fields that are not fully specified in [MS-OXCROPS].
The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetContentsTable ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14.1).
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] InputHandleIndex (1 byte): An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the input Server object is stored.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] InputHandleIndex (1 byte): The input Server object for this operation is a Folder object that represents the folder whose contents table will be retrieved.

[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): An integer that specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the output Server object is stored.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): The output Server object for this operation [RopGetContentsTable ROP] is a Table object that represents the contents table.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): For more details about Table objects, see [MS-OXCTABL].
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): A set of bits that control how information is returned in the contents table.

[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): The bits [0x02, 0x08, 0x10, 0x20, 0x40, 0x80] that SHOULD<9> be valid for this field [TableFlags] are specified in the following table.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] TableFlags (1 byte): The client MUST NOT set any other bits.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The bit name "Associated" has value "0x02".
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] If this bit [Associated] is set, the contents table lists only the FAI messages.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] If this bit [Associated] is not set, the contents table lists only the non-FAI messages.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] For details about FAI messages, see [MS-OXCMSG] section 1.3.2.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The bit name "DeferredErrors" has value "0x08".
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The ROP [RopGetContentsTable] response is returned immediately, possibly before the ROP execution is complete.

[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] And in this case [If the "DeferredErrors" is set to the TableFlags field], the values of the ReturnValue and the RowCount fields of the ROP [RopGetContentsTable] response buffer might not be accurate.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The bit name "NoNotifications" has value "0x10".
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] "NoNotification" is set to TableFlags field indicate: The contents table notifications to the client are disabled.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] Table notifications are specified in [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 2.2.1.1.1.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The bit name "SoftDeletes" has value "0x20".
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] If this bit [SoftDeletes] is set, the contents table lists only the messages that are soft deleted.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] If this bit [SoftDeletes] is not set, the contents table lists only the existing messages.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The listing of soft-deleted messages in a folder's contents table depends on whether the soft-deleted messages remain part of that folder's contents.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The location where soft-deleted messages are stored is up to the implementer of the protocol.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The bit name "UseUnicode" has value "0x40".
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] If this bit [UseUnicode] is set, the columns that contain string data are returned in Unicode format.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] If this bit [UseUnicode] is not set, the string data is encoded in the code page of the Logon object.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] The bit name "ConversationMembers" has value "0x80".

[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] "ConversationMembers" is set to TableFlags field indicate: The contents table lists messages pertaining to a single conversation (one result row represents a single message).
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] This bit [ConversationMembers] is valid only in conjunction with the UseUnicode bit and the DeferredErrors bit.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] This bit [ConversationMembers] is supported only on the Root folder of a mailbox and on public folders.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R10251, MS-OXCFOLD_R10252.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] This bit [ConversationMembers] is supported on the Root folder of a mailbox.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Request Buffer] This bit [ConversationMembers] is supported on public folders.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopGetContentsTable ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14.2).
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): An integer that indicates the result of the operation.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R332, MS-OXCFOLD_R671, MS-OXCFOLD_R672, MS-OXCFOLD_R1178, MS-OXCFOLD_R1179.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopGetContentsTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): The server returns 0x00000000 to indicate success.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): For details about common error codes, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Response Buffer] RowCount (4 bytes): An integer that specifies the number of rows in the contents table.

[In RopGetContentsTable ROP Response Buffer] RowCount (4 bytes): If the TableFlags field of the ROP request buffer has the DeferredErrors bit set, the value of the RowCount field might not be accurate.
[In Folder Object Properties] A Folder object can be created and modified by clients and servers.
[In Folder Object Properties] Except where noted, the constraints to which both clients and servers adhere when operating on a Folder object are defined in sections 2.2.2.1 through 2.2.2.2.2.7.
[In Folder Object Properties] Unless otherwise specified, a Folder object adheres to all property constraints specified in [MS-OXPROPS].
[In Folder Object Properties] A Folder object can also contain other properties, as specified in [MS-OXOSFLD] and [MS-OXOSRCH].
[In Folder Object Properties] When a property is specified as read-only, it means that the property can be set only by the server.
[In Folder Object Properties] [When a property is specified as read-only, it means that] Clients SHOULD NOT try to change the value of this property.
[In Folder Object Properties] For details about how the server handles a client's attempt to set a read-only property, see [MS-OXCPRPT] section 3.2.5.4.
[In General Properties] The following properties [PidTagAccess, PidTagChangeKey, PidTagCreationTime, PidTagLastModificationTime] exist on Folder objects as well as on other messaging objects.
[In General Properties] These properties [PidTagAccess, PidTagChangeKey, PidTagCreationTime, PidTagLastModificationTime] are set by the server.
[In General Properties] These properties [PidTagAccess, PidTagChangeKey, PidTagCreationTime, PidTagLastModificationTime] are read-only to the client.

[In General Properties] [The following properties exist on Folder objects as well as on other messaging objects. These properties are set by the server and are read-only to the client.] PidTagAccess ([MS-OXCPRPT] section 2.2.1.1) PidTagChangeKey ([MS-OXCFXICS] section 2.2.1.2.7) PidTagCreationTime ([MS-OXCMSG] section 2.2.2.3) PidTagLastModificationTime ([MS-OXCMSG] section 2.2.2.2)
[In Folder Object Specific Properties] The properties that are specific to a Folder object are specified in sections 2.2.2.2.1 and in 2.2.2.2.2.
[In PidTagContentCount Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagContentCount Property] The PidTagContentCount property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.640) specifies the number of messages in a folder, as computed by the message store.
[In PidTagContentCount Property] The value does not include FAI entries in the folder.
[In PidTagContentUnreadCount Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagContentUnreadCount Property] The PidTagContentUnreadCount property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.642) specifies the number of unread messages in a folder, as computed by the message store.
[In PidTagDeletedOn Property] Type: PtypTime ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagDeletedOn Property] The PidTagDeletedOn property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.664) specifies the time when the folder was soft deleted.
[In PidTagAddressBookEntryId Property] Type: PtypBinary ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)

[In PidTagAddressBookEntryId Property] The PidTagAddressBookEntryId property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.515) contains an Address Book EntryID structure, as specified in [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.5.2, that specifies the name-service entry ID of a directory object that refers to a public folder. <10>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R350002.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In PidTagAddressBookEntryId Property] This property is set only for public folders.
[In PidTagAddressBookEntryId Property] For details about public folders, see [MS-OXCSTOR] section 1.3.1.
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] The PidTagFolderId property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.695) contains a computed value that specifies the type or state of a folder.
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] The value is a bitwise OR of zero or more values [1: IPM, 2: SEARCH, 4: NORMAL, 8: RULES] from the following table.
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] [The folder flag named "IPM" specified] the folder belongs to the IPM subtree portion of the mailbox.
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] [The folder flag named "SEARCH" specified] the folder contains the results of a search.
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] [The folder flag named "NORMAL" specified] the folder is a generic folder that contains messages and other folders.
[In PidTagFolderFlags Property] [The folder flag named "RULES" specified] the folder has rules associated with it.
[In PidTagFolderId Property] Type: PtypInteger64 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagFolderId Property] The PidTagFolderId property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.694) contains a FID structure ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.1) that uniquely identifies a folder.
[In PidTagParentEntryId Property] Type: PtypBinary ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)

[In PidTagParentEntryId Property] The PidTagParentEntryId property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.852) contains a Folder EntryID structure, as specified in [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.4.1, that specifies the entry ID of the folder that contains the message or subfolder.
[In PidTagHierarchyChangeNumber Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagHierarchyChangeNumber Property] The PidTagHierarchyChangeNumber property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.714) specifies the number of subfolders in the folder.
[In PidTagHierarchyChangeNumber Property] The value of this property [PidTagHierarchyChangeNumber] monotonically increases every time a subfolder is added to or deleted from the folder.
[In PidTagHierRev Property] Type: PtypTime ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)

[In PidTagHierRev Property] The PidTagHierRev property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.715) specifies the time, in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), to trigger the client in cached mode to synchronize the folder hierarchy.
[In PidTagMessageSize Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagMessageSize Property] The PidTagMessageSize property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.790) specifies the aggregate size of messages in the folder.
[In PidTagMessageSizeExtended Property] Type: PtypInteger64 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagMessageSizeExtended Property] The PidTagMessageSizeExtended property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.791) specifies the 64-bit version of the PidTagMessageSize property (section 2.2.2.2.1.7).
[In PidTagSubfolders Property] Type: PtypBoolean ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagSubfolders Property] The PidTagSubfolders property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.1026) specifies whether the folder has any subfolders.
[In PidTagSubfolders Property] The value of this property [PidTagSubfolders] is nonzero if the folder has subfolders.
[In PidTagSubfolders Property] [if the folder does not have subfolders,] the value is zero otherwise.
[In PidTagLocalCommitTime Property] Type: PtypTime ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1).
[In PidTagLocalCommitTime Property] The PidTagLocalCommitTime property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.766) specifies the time, in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), that the folder was last changed.
[In PidTagLocalCommitTimeMax Property] Type: PtypTime ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1).
[In PidTagLocalCommitTimeMax Property] The PidTagLocalCommitTimeMax property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.767) specifies the most recent time that a top level object within a folder was changed.
[In PidTagLocalCommitTimeMax Property] Top level objects include messages and subfolders within the folder but not objects within the folder's subfolders.
[In PidTagDeletedCountTotal Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1).

[In PidTagDeletedCountTotal Property] The PidTagDeletedCountTotal property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.663) specifies the total number of messages that have been deleted from a folder, excluding messages that have been deleted from the folder's subfolders.
[In PidTagAttributeHidden Property] Type: PtypBoolean ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagAttributeHidden Property] The PidTagAttributeHidden property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.605) specifies whether the folder is hidden.
[In PidTagAttributeHidden Property] The value of this property [PidTagAttributeHidden] is nonzero if the folder is hidden.
[In PidTagAttributeHidden Property] The value is zero otherwise [If the folder is not hidden].
[In PidTagComment Property] Type: PtypString ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagComment Property] The PidTagComment property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.631) contains a comment about the purpose or content of the folder.
[In PidTagComment Property] This property [PidTagComment] is present only if the client sets it when the folder is created.
[In PidTagComment Property] The client sets the property [PidTagComment] by specifying a comment in the Comment field of the RopCreateFolder request (section 2.2.2.1).
[In PidTagContainerClass Property] Type: PtypString ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagContainerClass Property] The PidTagContainerClass property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.636) specifies the type of Message object that the folder contains.
[In PidTagContainerClass Property] The value of this property [PidTagContainerClass] MUST begin with "IPF.".
[PidTagContainerHierarchy Property] Type: PtypObject ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[PidTagContainerHierarchy Property] The PidTagContainerHierarchy property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.639) contains identifiers of the subfolders that are contained in the folder.
[PidTagContainerHierarchy Property] This property [PidTagContainerHierarchy] is used in a download operation, as specified in [MS-OXCFXICS] section 2.2.1.7 and section 3.2.5.10.
[In PidTagDisplayName Property] Type: PtypString ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagDisplayName Property] The PidTagDisplayName property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.670) specifies the display name of the folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R54.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In PidTagDisplayName Property] Sibling folders MUST have unique display names.
[PidTagFolderAssociatedContents Property] Type: PtypObject ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[PidTagFolderAssociatedContents Property] The PidTagFolderAssociatedContents property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.693) contains identifiers of the FAI messages that are contained in the folder.
[PidTagFolderAssociatedContents Property] This property [PidTagFolderAssociatedContents] is used in a download operation, as specified in [MS-OXCFXICS] section 2.2.1.7 and section 3.2.5.10.
[In PidTagFolderType Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagFolderType Property] The PidTagFolderType property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.696) specifies the type of the folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R810, MS-OXCFOLD_R811, MS-OXCFOLD_R812.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In PidTagFolderType Property] The valid values [0, 1, 2] of the PidTagFolderType property are listed in the following table.
[In PidTagFolderType Property] FOLDER_ROOT (0): The Root folder of the folder hierarchy table; that is, a folder that has no parent folder.
[In PidTagFolderType Property] FOLDER_GENERIC (1): A generic folder that contains messages and other folders.
[In PidTagFolderType Property] FOLDER_SEARCH (2): A folder that contains the results of a search, in the form of links to messages that meet search criteria.
[In PidTagRights Property] Type: PtypInteger32 ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagRights Property] This property's format is the same as that of the PidTagMemberRights property ([MS-OXCPERM] section 2.2.1.7).
[In PidTagRights Property] The PidTagRights property ([MS-OXPROPS] section 2.929) specifies the client's folder permissions.
[In PidTagRights Property] The FreeBusyDetailed flag and the FreeBusySimple flag do not apply to the PidTagRights property.
[In PidTagAccessControlListData Property] Type: PtypBinary ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.11.1)
[In PidTagAccessControlListData Property] The PidTagAccessControlListData property ([MS-OXCPERM] section 2.2.3) contains the access control list (ACL) of the folder.<11>
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol.
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.

[In Abstract Data Model] This document [Folder Object Protocol Specification] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model, as long as their external behavior is consistent with that specified in this document[Folder Object Protocol Specification].
[In Hierarchy Table] A hierarchy table contains information about the subfolders contained in a folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R801, MS-OXCFOLD_R802, MS-OXCFOLD_R805, MS-OXCFOLD_R809.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Hierarchy Table] Each row of a hierarchy table contains a set of columns with information about one folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R801, MS-OXCFOLD_R802, MS-OXCFOLD_R805, MS-OXCFOLD_R809.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Hierarchy Table] A hierarchy table is implemented by message store providers and is used primarily by clients to show the hierarchy within a folder, displayed as a tree of folders and subfolders.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R801, MS-OXCFOLD_R802, MS-OXCFOLD_R805, MS-OXCFOLD_R809.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Hierarchy Table] The following are the two types of hierarchy tables: Standard, Soft deleted.
[In Hierarchy Table] The standard table contains only folders that were not deleted.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R801, MS-OXCFOLD_R802, MS-OXCFOLD_R805, MS-OXCFOLD_R809.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Hierarchy Table] The soft-deleted table contains only folders that have been soft deleted.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R806.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Hierarchy Table] A hierarchy table is obtained by using the RopGetHierarchyTable ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.13).
[In Contents Table] A contents table contains information about the Message objects contained in a folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R662, MS-OXCFOLD_R663, MS-OXCFOLD_R1014, MS-OXCFOLD_R1017, MS-OXCFOLD_R665, MS-OXCFOLD_R1023.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Contents Table] Each row of a contents table contains a set of columns with information about one Message object.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R662, MS-OXCFOLD_R663, MS-OXCFOLD_R1014, MS-OXCFOLD_R1017, MS-OXCFOLD_R665, MS-OXCFOLD_R1023.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Contents Table] A contents table is implemented by message store providers and is used primarily by clients and to show the messages contained in a folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R662, MS-OXCFOLD_R663, MS-OXCFOLD_R1014, MS-OXCFOLD_R1017, MS-OXCFOLD_R665, MS-OXCFOLD_R1023.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Contents Table] The following are the four types of contents tables: Standard, Standard soft deleted, FAI, FAI soft deleted.
[In Contents Table] A standard contents table contains only standard (non-FAI) messages.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R663.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Contents Table] A FAI contents table contains only FAI messages.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R662.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Contents Table] For more information about FAI messages, see [MS-OXCMSG] section 1.3.2.
[In Contents Table] The soft-deleted views contain only messages that have been soft deleted.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R1017.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Contents Table] A contents table is obtained by using the RopGetContentsTable ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14).
[In Opening a Folder] Before any data can be read from or written to a folder, the client opens the folder.
[In Opening a Folder] The client MUST have sufficient access rights to the folder for this operation to succeed.
[In Opening a Folder] To open an existing folder, the client sends the RopOpenFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.1).
[In Opening a Folder] To send this request [RopOpenFolder request], the client first obtains the FID ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.1) for the Folder object to be opened.

[In Opening a Folder] The FID can be retrieved from the hierarchy table that contains the folder's information by including the PidTagFolderId property (section 2.2.2.2.1.6) in a RopSetColumns request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.5.1.1).
[In Opening a Folder] The Folder object that is opened can be used in subsequent operations.
[In Opening a Folder] When the client completes operations on the Folder object, the client MUST release the object as specified in section 3.1.5.1.
[In Creating a Folder] Before any data can be read from or written to a folder, the client opens the folder as specified in section 3.1.4.1.
[In Creating a Folder] If the folder does not exist, the client creates the folder.
[In Creating a Folder] Before a folder can be created, the parent folder MUST already exist.
[In Creating a Folder] To create a folder, the client sends the RopCreateFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.2).
[In Creating a Folder] The Folder object that is returned by the RopCreateFolder ROP can be used in subsequent operations.
[In Creating a Folder] When the client completes operations on the Folder object, the client MUST release the object as specified in section 3.1.5.1.
[In Deleting a Folder] To be deleted, a folder MUST exist, and the client needs the access rights to delete it.
[In Deleting a Folder] To delete a folder, the client sends a RopDeleteFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.3).
[In Deleting a Folder] If the folder is not empty, the client sets the DeleteFolderFlags field to delete all existing subfolders and messages, as specified in section 2.2.1.3.1.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R82.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Deleting a Folder] The DeleteFolderFlags field can also be used to specify a hard deletion, when the DELETE_HARD_DELETE bit is set.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R764.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Deleting a Folder] The PartialCompletion field of the ROP response, as specified in section 2.2.1.3.2, indicates whether there are any subfolders or messages that could not be deleted and, consequently, that the folder was not deleted.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Setting Up a Search Folder] The client creates a search folder by using the RopCreateFolder ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.2) with the FolderType field set to the value 2, as specified in section 2.2.1.2.1.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] For details about creating a folder, see section 3.1.4.2.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] The client fills a search folder by applying search criteria and a search scope to the search folder.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] The search criteria determine which messages are included in the folder, and the search scope determines the folders that are searched.

[In Setting Up a Search Folder] To set the search criteria and search scope for a search folder, the client sends a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.4) with bits of the SearchFlags field set to control the details of how the search is performed, as specified in section 2.2.1.4.1.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] The ROP request includes restrictions to specify the search criteria and FIDs ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.1) to specify the search scope.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] A search folder cannot be included in its own search scope.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] [A search folder cannot be included in its own search scope] Therefore, the FolderIds field MUST NOT include the FID of the search folder.

[In Setting Up a Search Folder] To access the results of a search, the client sends a RopGetContentsTable ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14) to obtain the contents table of the search folder, as specified in section 3.1.4.10.

[In Setting Up a Search Folder] [To access the results of a search, the client sends a RopGetContentsTable ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14) to obtain the contents table of the search folder, as specified in section 3.1.4.10.] The messages that match the search criteria are specified in the table.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] When the client is finished using a search folder, the folder can either be deleted or remain open for later use.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] Note that if the search folder is deleted, only message links are deleted.
[In Setting Up a Search Folder] [If the search folder is deleted,] the actual messages remain in their [folder's] parent folders.

[In Getting Details About a Search Folder] To obtain details about a search folder, the client sends a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.5) with the appropriate values in the IncludeRestriction and IncludeFolders fields, as specified in section 2.2.1.5.1, to specify the details to be included in the response.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R130, MS-OXCFOLD_R129, MS-OXCFOLD_R131, MS-OXCFOLD_R132.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Getting Details About a Search Folder] The details about a search folder can include the search criteria, a list of the folders that are being searched, and the status of the search folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R1108, MS-OXCFOLD_R701, MS-OXCFOLD_R173, MS-OXCFOLD_R1115, MS-OXCFOLD_R200, MS-OXCFOLD_R1123, MS-OXCFOLD_R230, MS-OXCFOLD_R1132, MS-OXCFOLD_R248, MS-OXCFOLD_R1140, MS-OXCFOLD_R267, MS-OXCFOLD_R1150, MS-OXCFOLD_R289, MS-OXCFOLD_R1157.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Getting Details About a Search Folder] For details about how the client sets up a search folder, see section 3.1.4.4.

[In Moving a Folder and Its Contents] To move particular messages from one folder to another, the client sends a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.6) with the WantCopy field set to zero (FALSE), as specified in section 2.2.1.6.1.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R159, MS-OXCFOLD_R160.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Moving a Folder and Its Contents] The client's request includes a list of MIDs ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.2) that specify the messages to be moved.
[In Moving a Folder and Its Contents] To move a folder from one parent folder to another, the client sends a RopMoveFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.7).
[In Moving a Folder and Its Contents] All of the folder's messages and subfolders are moved with the folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R170.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Moving a Folder and Its Contents] The RopMoveCopyMessages ROP request and RopMoveFolder ROP request are processed asynchronously if the client sets the WantAsynchronous field of the request to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in sections 2.2.1.6.1 and 2.2.1.7.1.
[In Moving a Folder and Its Contents] For details about asynchronous processing, see section 3.1.5.2.

[In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] To copy particular messages from one folder to another, the client sends a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.6) with the WantCopy field set to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.6.1.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R159, MS-OXCFOLD_R160.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] The client's request includes a list of MIDs ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.2) that specify the messages to be copied.
[In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] To copy a folder from one parent folder to another, the client sends a RopCopyFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.8).
[In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] All of the messages in the source folder are duplicated in the new folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R198.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] If the WantRecursive field is set to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.8.1, the subfolders that are contained in the source folder are also duplicated in the new folder.

[In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] The RopMoveCopyMessages ROP request and RopCopyFolder ROP request are processed asynchronously if the client sets the WantAsynchronous field of the request to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in sections 2.2.1.6.1 and 2.2.1.7.1.
[In Copying a Folder and Its Contents] For details about asynchronous processing, see section 3.1.5.2.

[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] To delete all messages and subfolders from a folder without deleting the folder itself, the client sends either a RopEmptyFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.9) [or a RopHardDeleteMessagesAndSubfolders ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.10)].

[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] To delete all messages and subfolders from a folder without deleting the folder itself, the client sends [either a RopEmptyFolder ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.9)] or a RopHardDeleteMessagesAndSubfolders ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.10).
[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] The client uses the RopEmptyFolder ROP for a soft delete [and the RopHardDeleteMessagesAndSubfolders ROP for a hard delete].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R225.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] The client uses [the RopEmptyFolder ROP for a soft delete and] the RopHardDeleteMessagesAndSubfolders ROP for a hard delete.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R113801.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] A message that has been soft deleted [only for RopEmptyFolder] can be recovered only by opening it, copying its contents to a new message, and then saving the new message.
[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] For details about opening and saving a Message object, see [MS-OXCMSG].
[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] For details about copying a Message object from one folder to another, see section 3.1.4.7.

[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] To remove particular messages from a folder, the client sends [either] a RopDeleteMessages ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.11) [or a RopHardDeleteMessages ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.12)].

[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] To remove particular messages from a folder, the client sends [either a RopDeleteMessages ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.11) or] a RopHardDeleteMessages ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.12).
[In Deleting the Contents of a Folder] For details about asynchronous processing, see section 3.1.5.2.

[In Getting a Hierarchy Table] To retrieve a hierarchy table that is associated with a folder, the client sends a RopGetHierarchyTable ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.13) with the appropriate bits set in the TableFlags field, as specified in section 2.2.1.13.1.
[In Getting a Hierarchy Table] Subsequent operations can be executed on the Table object that is returned by the RopGetHierarchyTable ROP.
[In Getting a Hierarchy Table] When the client completes operations on the Table object, the client MUST release the object as specified in section 3.1.5.1.

[In Getting a Contents Table] To retrieve a contents table that is associated with a folder, the client sends a RopGetContentsTable ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.14) with the appropriate bits set in the TableFlags field, as specified in section 2.2.1.14.1.
[In Getting a Contents Table] Subsequent operations can be executed on the Table object that is returned by RopGetContentsTable ROP.
[In Getting a Contents Table] When the client completes operations on the Table object, the client MUST release the object as specified in section 3.1.5.1.
[In Getting a Contents Table] For conversation view, the client sets the ConversationMembers bit in the TableFlags field of the RopGetContentsTable request.

[In Getting a Contents Table] After sending this request [RopGetContentsTable], the client sends a RopRestrict request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.5.3) to limit the view to the messages of a particular conversation, as specified in [MS-OXCTABL].

[In Releasing a Server Object] The client MUST send a RopRelease ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.15.3.1) to release the Server object after executing all subsequent operations on the folder that was [created or] opened.

[In Releasing a Server Object] The client MUST send a RopRelease ROP request ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.15.3.1) to release the Server object after executing all subsequent operations on the folder that was created [or opened].
[In Releasing a Server Object] Likewise, the client MUST send a RopRelease ROP request after executing all subsequent operations on [a contents table or] a hierarchy table.
[In Releasing a Server Object] Likewise, the client MUST send a RopRelease ROP request after executing all subsequent operations on a contents table [or a hierarchy table].
[In Releasing a Server Object] If the client does not send a RopRelease ROP request, the server does not free the resources associated with the Folder object or the Table object.
[In Releasing a Server Object] For details about Server object dependencies and releasing resources, see [MS-OXCROPS] sections 3.1.5.3 and 3.2.5.3.

[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] Some ROPs [RopMoveCopyMessages (section 2.2.1.6), RopMoveFolder (section 2.2.1.7), RopCopyFolder (section 2.2.1.8), RopEmptyFolder (section 2.2.1.9), RopHardDeleteMessagesAndSubfolders (section 2.2.1.10), RopDeleteMessages (section 2.2.1.11), RopHardDeleteMessages (section 2.2.1.12)] can be processed asynchronously.

[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] During asynchronous processing, the client receives a RopProgress ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.13) instead of the ROP response buffer that corresponds to the ROP request buffer that the client sent.
[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] The RopProgress ROP response indicates that the operation is still being processed.
[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] When processing is complete, the client receives the ROP response buffer that corresponds to the original ROP request buffer.

[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] Any of the following ROPs can be processed asynchronously if its ROP request buffer was sent with the WantAsynchronous field set to nonzero (TRUE). RopMoveCopyMessages (section 2.2.1.6) RopMoveFolder (section 2.2.1.7) RopCopyFolder (section 2.2.1.8) RopEmptyFolder (section 2.2.1.9) RopHardDeleteMessagesAndSubfolders (section 2.2.1.10) RopDeleteMessages (section 2.2.1.11) RopHardDeleteMessages (section 2.2.1.12)
[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] The client can send a RopProgress ROP request buffer either to abort an in-progress operation or to get information about the progress of an operation.
[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] The client can send a RopProgress ROP request buffer to abort an in-progress operation.
[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] The client can send a RopProgress ROP request buffer to get information about the progress of an operation.
[In Processing ROPs Asynchronously] For more details about the RopProgress ROP, see [MS-OXCPRPT] sections 2.2.22 and 3.2.5.19.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol.
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.

[In Abstract Data Model] This document [Folder Object Protocol Specification] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model, as long as their external behavior is consistent with that specified in this document[Folder Object Protocol Specification].
[In Abstract Data Model] The abstract data model used by the server and the client are the same.
[In Higher-Layer Triggered Events] Various agents on the server could issue the same higher-layer triggered events, as specified in section 3.1.4.
[In Higher-Layer Triggered Events] The same considerations specified in section 3.1.4 for client implementations also apply to server implementations.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] When the server receives a RopOpenFolder ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.1) from the client, the server parses the buffer.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server responds with a RopOpenFolder ROP response buffer.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server parses buffers and processes ROPs, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.1.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The RopOpenFolder ROP succeeds only if a folder with the specified ID actually exists<10> and the client has sufficient access rights to view the folder.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] If a folder with the specified ID does not exist, the server either fails the RopOpenfolder ROP or not<12> .
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R46201001, MS-OXCFOLD_R46201002.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] If the folder with the specified ID actually exists and the client has sufficient access rights to view the folder, the RopOpenFolder ROP performs successfully.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server opens the folder according to the setting of the OpenSoftDeleted bit of the OpenModeFlags field of the ROP request buffer.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R22, MS-OXCFOLD_R21.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore any invalid bits [0x01, 0x02, 0x08, 0x10, 0x20, 0x40, 0x80] that are set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x01" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x02" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x08" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x10" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x20" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x40" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The server MUST ignore invalid bit "0x80" that is set in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The following specific error codes [ecNotFound, ecNotSupported] apply to this ROP [RopOpenFolder].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R468, MS-OXCFOLD_R469, MS-OXCFOLD_R470, MS-OXCFOLD_R471, MS-OXCFOLD_R472, MS-OXCFOLD_R473.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] For more details about ROP errors, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotFound is 0x8004010F.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotFound, it indicates the FID ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.1) does not correspond to a folder in the database.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotFound, it indicates the client does not have rights to the folder.

[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotFound, it indicates the folder is soft-deleted and the client has not specified the OpenSoftDeleted bit in the OpenModeFlags field.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSupported is 0x80040102.
[In Processing a RopOpenFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the object that this ROP [RopOpenFolder ROP] was called on is not a Folder object or Logon object.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the server receives a RopCreateFolder ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.2) from the client, the server parses the buffer.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The server responds with a RopCreateFolder ROP response buffer.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server parses buffers and processes ROPs, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.1.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] A folder name in the DisplayName field of the ROP request buffer, as specified in section 2.2.1.2.1, MUST be specified to create a folder.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] A folder description, specified in the Comment field of the ROP request buffer, is optional.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The folder name MUST be unique within the parent folder.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] In other words, sibling folders cannot have the same name.

[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] If a folder with the same name already exists, and the OpenExisting field is set to zero (FALSE), the server fails the RopCreateFolder ROP request with error code ecDuplicateName.

[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] If a folder with the same name already exists and the OpenExisting field is set to nonzero (TRUE), the server opens the existing folder, behaving as if it is processing the RopOpenFolder ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.1).
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] If a folder with the same name does not exist, the server creates a new folder, regardless of the value of the OpenExisting field.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] If the client does not have permissions to create the folder, the server returns either ecAccessdenied or ecNoCreateSubfolderRight. <13>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R106601, MS-OXCFOLD_R106602.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The following specific error codes [ecInvalidParam, ecError, ecAccessdenied, ecDuplicateName, ecNotSupported, ecNotFound, ecNoCreateSubfolderRight] apply to this ROP [RopCreateFolder].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R486, MS-OXCFOLD_R487, MS-OXCFOLD_R1069, MS-OXCFOLD_R1070, MS-OXCFOLD_R1071, MS-OXCFOLD_R489, MS-OXCFOLD_R491, MS-OXCFOLD_R493, MS-OXCFOLD_R494, MS-OXCFOLD_R495, MS-OXCFOLD_R49601, MS-OXCFOLD_R1072, MS-OXCFOLD_R1073, MS-OXCFOLD_R1074, MS-OXCFOLD_R1075.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] For more details about ROP errors, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecInvalidParam is 0x80070057.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecInvalidParam, it indicates the FolderType field contains an invalid value.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecError is 0x80004005.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecError, it indicates the operation failed for an unspecified reason.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecAccessdenied is 0x80070005.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecAccessDenied, it indicates the client does not have permissions to create the folder.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecDuplicateName is 0x80040604.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecDuplicateName, it indicates a folder with the same name already exists, and the OpenExisting field was set to zero (FALSE).
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSupported is 0x80040102.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the object that this ROP [RopCreateFolder ROP] was called on an object that is not a Folder object.

[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the object that this ROP [RopCreateFolder ROP] was called to create a search folder on a public folders message store.<14>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R10660201, MS-OXCFOLD_R10660202.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotFound is 0x8004010F.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotFound, it indicates the ROP was called on a Folder object that is a soft delete folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNoCreateSubfolderRight is 0x00000502.
[In Processing a RopCreateFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNoCreateSubfolderRight, it indicates the client does not have access rights to create the folder.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the server receives a RopDeleteFolder ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.3) from the client, the server parses the buffer.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] The server responds with a RopDeleteFolder ROP response buffer.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server parses buffers and processes ROPs, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.1.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] If the DELETE_HARD_DELETE bit of the DeleteFolderFlags field of the ROP request buffer is set, as specified in section 2.2.1.3.1, the folder MUST be removed and can no longer be accessed by the client with subsequent ROPs.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] If the DELETE_HARD_DELETE bit is not set, the folder becomes soft deleted.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] If the DEL_MESSAGES bit is not set and the folder contains Message objects, neither the folder nor any of its Message objects will be deleted.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] If the DEL_FOLDERS bit is not set and the folder contains subfolders, neither the folder nor any of its subfolders will be deleted.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] [If the DEL_MESSAGES bit is not set and the folder contains Message objects, neither the folder nor any of its Message objects will be deleted], the ReturnValue field of the ROP response, as specified in section 2.2.1.3.2, will be set to 0x00000000.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] [If the DEL_MESSAGES bit is not set and the folder contains Message objects, neither the folder nor any of its Message objects will be deleted], the PartialCompletion field will be set to a nonzero (TRUE) value.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] [If the DEL_FOLDERS bit is not set and the folder contains subfolders, neither the folder nor any of its subfolders will be deleted], the ReturnValue field of the ROP response, as specified in section 2.2.1.3.2, will be set to 0x00000000.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] And [if the DEL_FOLDERS bit is not set and the folder contains subfolders, neither the folder nor any of its subfolders will be deleted], the PartialCompletion field will be set to a nonzero (TRUE) value.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] If the client sets an invalid bit in the DeleteFolderFlags field of the ROP request buffer, the server SHOULD<13> fail the ROP with an ecInvalidParam (0x80070057) error.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R123401, MS-OXCFOLD_R123402.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] The following specific error codes [ecAccessDenied, ecNotFound, ecInvalidParam, ecNotSupported] apply to this ROP [RopDeleteFolder].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R2500, MS-OXCFOLD_R502, MS-OXCFOLD_R503, MS-OXCFOLD_R1235, MS-OXCFOLD_R1236, MS-OXCFOLD_R504, MS-OXCFOLD_R507, MS-OXCFOLD_R508, MS-OXCFOLD_R510, MS-OXCFOLD_R509, MS-OXCFOLD_R2509.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] For more details about ROP errors, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecAccessDenied is 0x80070005.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecAccessDenied, it indicates the client does not have permissions to delete this folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecInvalidParam is 0x80070057.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecInvalidParam, it indicates an invalid value was specified in a field.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotFound is 0x8004010F.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotFound, it indicates folder with the specified ID does not exist.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotFound, it indicates the client has no access to view that folder.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSupported is 0x80040102.
[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the object that this ROP [RopDeleteFolder ROP] was called on is not a Folder object.

[In Processing a RopDeleteFolder ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the object that this ROP [RopDeleteFolder ROP] was called on is an attempt was made to delete the Root folder..
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the server receives a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.4) from the client, the server parses the buffer.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server responds with a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP response buffer.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For details about how the server parses buffers and processes ROPs, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.1.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server fills the search folder according to the search criteria and search scope that are specified in the RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The messages that satisfy the search criteria appear as links in the search folder.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When new search criteria are applied, the server modifies the search folder to include only the messages that match the new search criteria.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server can return the RopSetSearchCriteria ROP response before the search folder is fully updated.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For static search folders, the contents of the search folder are not updated after the initial population is complete.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For dynamic search folders, the contents of the search folder MUST continue to be updated as messages move around the mailbox.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For dynamic search folders, the contents of the search folder MUST continue to be updated as messages start to match or cease to match the search criteria.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] A static search causes the search folder to be populated once with all messages that match the search criteria at the point in time when the search is started or restarted.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server MUST NOT update the search folder after the initial population when new messages that match the search criteria arrive in the search scope.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] Or the server MUST NOT update the search folder after the initial population when existing messages that fit the search criteria are deleted.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] To trigger an update, another RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request with the RESTART_SEARCH bit set in the SearchFlags field, as specified in section 2.2.1.4.1, is required.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] A dynamic search causes the search folder to be initially populated with all messages that match the search criteria at the point in time when the search is started or restarted.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server continues to update the search folder with messages that enter or exit the search criteria.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] A RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request with the STOP_SEARCH bit set does not have any effect on a dynamic search that has already completed its initial population.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] And a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request with the STOP_SEARCH bit set, also does not change the dynamic nature of the search folder.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server can use context indexing by default at the discretion of the server implementation.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] Whether it [context indexing] is used is usually based on the nature of the restriction that is used.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When using context indexing in searches, the server allows the client to quickly search text in messages through the use of prebuilt indexes, while searches that are not content-indexed are based on a sequential scan of all the messages in the search scope and can be expensive.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] In the worst case, a search that is not content-indexed can involve the entire contents of the mailbox while holding an exclusive lock on the mailbox.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] A content-indexed search MAY<16> be static regardless of the value of the STATIC_SEARCH bit in the RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R1238001, MS-OXCFOLD_R1238002.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] Some differences between searches that are content-indexed and those that are not content-indexed are listed in the following table.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request, the difference between content-indexed and not content-indexed searches is that] Content-indexed search is Based on words, phrases, and sentences, not content-indexed search is Based on a stream of bytes.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request, the difference between content-indexed and not content-indexed searches is that] Content-indexed search ignores punctuation and spaces and is also not case sensitive, not content-indexed search finds only an exact match of all characters.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request, the difference between content-indexed and not content-indexed searches is that] Content-indexed search searches within attachment types that are supported by the installed filters, not content-indexed search does not search within attachments.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request, the difference between content-indexed and not content-indexed searches is that] Content-indexed search uses full-text index to locate records, not content-indexed search performs a serial scan of the entire folder.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request, the difference between content-indexed and not content-indexed searches is that] Content-indexed search supports only full-text searches, not content-indexed search supports the full set of restrictions, which includes nontext property types such as date and time. Does not use a full-text search.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the server receives a subsequent RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request in which neither STOP_SEARCH nor RESTART_SEARCH is set or in which neither RECURSIVE_SEARCH nor SHALLOW_SEARCH is set, the server SHOULD<17> use the default values.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] If the STOP_SEARCH bit is set in the SearchFlags field, the server SHOULD stop the initial population of the search folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCFOLD_R54301.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] Due to the asynchronous nature of the call, the server can complete the operation before the RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request with STOP_SEARCH is serviced.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server can take some time to stop and might not stop at all.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] If the RESTART_SEARCH bit is set in the SearchFlags field, the server restarts the population of the search folder.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] If the client does not specify FIDs, as specified in ([MS-OXCDATA] section 2.2.1.1), in the initial RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request, the server fails the ROP with ecNotInitialized (0x80040605).

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] If the client does not specify FIDs in a subsequent RopSetSearchCriteria ROP request, the server uses the FIDs that were specified in the previous request.

[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] If the client sets the search scope to include the search folder itself, the server SHOULD<18> fail the ROP with ecSearchFolderScopeViolation (0x00000490).
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R124201, MS-OXCFOLD_R124202.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] If the client sets an invalid bit in the SearchFlags field, the server SHOULD<19> fail the ROP with the error code ecInvalidParam (0x80070057).
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R116001, MS-OXCFOLD_R116002.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The following specific error codes [ecInvalidParam, ecNotInitialized, ecNotSearchFolder, ecSearchFolderScopeViolation, ecTooComplex, ecNotSupported] apply to this ROP [RopSetSearchCriteria].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R1091, MS-OXCFOLD_R1092, MS-OXCFOLD_R565, MS-OXCFOLD_R566, MS-OXCFOLD_R569, MS-OXCFOLD_R570, MS-OXCFOLD_R1243, MS-OXCFOLD_R1244, MS-OXCFOLD_R2570, MS-OXCFOLD_R572, MS-OXCFOLD_R573, MS-OXCFOLD_R574, MS-OXCFOLD_R575.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For more details about ROP errors, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecInvalidParam is 0x80070057.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecInvalidParam, it indicates the SearchFlags field contains an invalid value.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotInitialized is 0x80040605.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotInitialized, it indicates that no FIDs were specified for this search folder.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSearchFolder is 0x00000461.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSearchFolder, it indicates the object is not a search folder.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecSearchFolderScopeViolation is 0x00000490.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecSearchFolderScopeViolation, it indicates the search folder was included in its own search scope.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecTooComplex is 0x80040117.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecTooComplex, it indicates restriction is too complex.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSupported is 0x80040102.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the object that this ROP [RopSetSearchCriteria] was called on is not a Folder object.
[In Processing a RopSetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates the request specified a recursive search on a public folder.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the server receives a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.5) from the client, the server parses the buffer.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server responds with a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP response buffer.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For details about how the server parses buffers and processes ROPs, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.1.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.

[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server returns the search criteria only if the IncludeRestriction field of the ROP [RopGetSearchCriteria] request buffer is set to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.5.1.

[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The server returns a list of the folders that are being searched only if the IncludeFolders field of the ROP [RopGetSearchCriteria] request buffer is set to nonzero (TRUE).
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The following specific error codes [ecNotSearchFolder, ecNotSupported] apply to this ROP [RopGetSearchCriteria].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R579, MS-OXCFOLD_R580, MS-OXCFOLD_R581, MS-OXCFOLD_R582.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] For more details about ROP errors, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSearchFolder is 0x00000461.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSearchFolder, it indicates that the object is not a search folder.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSupported is 0x80040102.
[In Processing a RopGetSearchCriteria ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates that the object that this ROP [RopGetSearchCriteria ROP] was called on is not a Folder object.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] When the server receives a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP request buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.4.6) from the client, the server parses the buffer.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] The server responds with a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP response buffer.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] For details about how the server parses buffers and processes ROPs, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.1.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.

[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] If the server fails to move or copy any message, it sets the PartialCompletion field of the RopMoveCopyMessages ROP response buffer to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.6.2.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] If the client requests asynchronous execution, the server executes this ROP [RopMoveCopyMessages ROP] asynchronously.

[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] During asynchronous processing, the server can return a RopProgress ROP response buffer ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.13) to indicate that the operation is still processing.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] During asynchronous processing, the server can return a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP response buffer to indicate that the operation has already completed.

[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] If the operation [RopMoveCopyMessages] fails at any point during the asynchronous processing, the server returns a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP response buffer with an appropriate error code.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] For details about the RopProgress ROP and how it is used, see [MS-OXCPRPT] sections 2.2.22 and 3.2.5.19.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] The following specific error codes [ecNotSupported, ecSearchFolder] apply to this ROP [RopMoveCopyMessages].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by requirements: MS-OXCFOLD_R589, MS-OXCFOLD_R590, MS-OXCFOLD_R1245, MS-OXCFOLD_R1246.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] For more details about ROP errors, see [MS-OXCDATA] section 2.4.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] The value of error code ecNotSupported is 0x80040102.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] When the error code is ecNotSupported, it indicates that either the source object or the destination object is not a Folder object.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] The value of error code ecSearchFolder is 0x00000460.
[In Processing a RopMoveCopyMessages ROP Request] When the error code is ecSearchFolder, it indicates the destination object is a search folder.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

[In Processing a RopMoveFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.

[In Processing a RopMoveFolder ROP Request] If the server fails to move any folder, message, or subfolder, it sets the PartialCompletion field of the RopMoveFolder ROP response buffer to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.7.2.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

[In Processing a RopCopyFolder ROP Request] For details about how the server formats buffers for the response, see [MS-OXCROPS] section 3.2.5.2.
[In Processing a RopCopyFolder ROP Request] All messages contained in the source folder MUST be duplicated in the new folder.

[In Processing a RopCopyFolder ROP Request] If the server fails to copy any folder, message, or subfolder, it sets the PartialCompletion field of the RopCopyFolder ROP response buffer to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.8.2.

[In Processing a RopCopyFolder ROP Request] If the WantRecursive field of the RopCopyFolder ROP request buffer is set to nonzero (TRUE), as specified in section 2.2.1.8.1, the subfolders contained in the source folder are also duplicated in the new folder in a recursive manner.
[In Processing a RopCopyFolder ROP Request] If the client requests asynchronous execution, the server executes this ROP asynchronously.
[In Processing a RopCopyFolder ROP Request] During asynchronous processing, the server can return a RopCopyFolder ROP response buffer to indicate that the operation has already completed.
